text: the Boy Scouts of America is considering
a policy change to allow local troops to
admit openly gay scouts and Scout
masters
I'm Marcus Mabry for The New York Times
the Supreme Court ruled in a 2000
landmark decision that a private
organization like the Boy Scouts was
allowed to exclude gay members the case
was brought by James Dale an openly gay
Scoutmaster who was dismissed by his
troop after it learned of his sexual
orientation but now 13 years later the
scouts are considering a change mr. Dale
is here now along with Evan Wolfson the
attorney who argued his case before the
Supreme Court thank you both for being
here
thank you James let me start with you
you're surprised by the fact that the
scouts are considering this policy
change I'm surprised that it's taking
the Boy Scouts 13 years since the
Supreme Court to take another look at
their policy which still discriminates
evidence there are a legal reason to
explain this this change this
consideration well the Supreme Court in
2000 and James's case said that the Boy
Scouts have a right to discriminate but
they didn't say it is right to
discriminate and what's happened since
James's case is that parents kids
corporations cities the public have said
to the scouts we don't agree with this
policy this is wrong and the scouts are
finally now trying to get in step with a
public that has moved far beyond and
with their own members who never voted
for this policy in the first place this
is not about them being forced to do
this
by the law this is about them being
forced to do it in order to stay with
where today's youth are and where the
America's understanding of fairness is
as you said one thing we've seen is some
scout staff and former Scouts and the
Eagle Scouts coming out and saying in
fact I'm LGBT and and I feel
discriminated against let's listen to
one of those voices what they have had
to had to say on YouTube right now hi my
name is Derrick I've served 10 years on
the manual summer camp branch staff
working my way up from outdoor skills
instructor all the way to program
director and I am gay
do you think people like James like
Derek Nance are actually making a
difference and coming out and saying
what they're saying I think of course
they make a difference I think that it's
a horrible position the Boy Scouts are
doing to young people making them choose
between being true to themselves and
lying to an organization I think that
the Boy Scouts are doing so much damage
in the policy they should be reviewing
next week should be one of no
discrimination not just a compromised
position which is what they're debating
now then you need to go full force and
make sure that they're not harming any
more children and next week it's a
meeting of the National Executive of the
Boy Scouts are they behind this change
do you think I mean we're their local
troops there's also a national executive
who do you think is behind the actual
policy consideration my gut tells me
that the the leadership in Texas didn't
start this I think it's the Board of
Directors Chairman like people from AT&T
and corporations that solicit gay and
lesbian employees they want the best
possible talent whether they're gay
lesbian bisexual or transgender so I
think that kind of put the Boy Scouts
leadership the paid executives in Texas
and in a difficult position I think they
were their hand was forced but I think
the policy they put forward just the
other day doesn't go far enough do you
think there's a possibility though now
of Korean have kind of divided scouting
movement in the u.s. we have red states
calcine blue states go well
interestingly enough the two recent
presidential candidates Obama and also
Mitt Romney were both against this
policy Romney the Republican candidate
was even a member of the Boy Scouts
Executive Board he was against this
policy so I think it's moved beyond red
and blue I think this is about America
and what's right for America you say the
Boy Scouts have not gone far enough yet
what do you intend to do or is it
anything that the supporters of going
farther intend to do to make them go
farther and are you afraid of a backlash
I think when the Boy Scouts had an
anti-gay policy when they brought about
this anti-gay policy in the 90s and with
the Supreme Court decision in 2000 it
was top-down I think they're gonna have
a non-discrimination policy it should be
top-down as well they shouldn't just
kick the can down the road I completely
agree with that look permission to
discriminate as a policy is better than
mandatory discrimination but what it
still does is bring kids gay and non-gay
into an organization that's teaching
it's okay to discriminate and that's not
what scouting is a
out scouting says it's open to all boys
there should be no asterisk it should be
open to all without discrimination and
they should teach the values of respect
standing up for one another
diversity and doing the great things
that scouting can offer and I agree with
James and I think the pressure will not
stop from within as well as from
companies and others until they go to a
clear policy of non-discrimination is
there a role for the Supreme Court to
see here and reversing its former
decision or not well the Supreme Court
did get it wrong five to four in 2000
but what the good news here is that we
may have lost the case five to four but
we've won the cause America has come to
understand this is wrong and parents and
members of scouts and supporters of
Scouts are the ones who are speaking out
and that's why this change is happening
the world has changed since 2000 and the
case the military no longer
discriminates the president who's the
honorary chair of the Boy Scouts clearly
does not support discrimination parents
have spoken with their feet companies
have spoken with their dollars the
scouting organization is scrambling to
get in touch with kids today and they
need to do that by embracing
non-discrimination across the board I
think what the Supreme Court did was
they pushed the decision back down to
the people they pushed it down to people
like Derrick they push it down to my mom
and dad whether people want to be
associated with an organization that
discriminates I think the past 13 years
have told us America doesn't want to be
on the side of discrimination all right
it's a movement and a change we'll keep
watching thank you both for being here
thank you that's all for now we'll be
